episodes.title: Episode 3 | Oops, I Married a White Supremacist
episodes.description:
Sitting at my desk, working on what will become my first memoir, I still can’t believe somebody wants to publish this story about my childhood in the infamous Children of God cult and career in another sort of cult—the USArmy. But after the recent events of January 6, it also seemed inevitable. Suddenly everyone was asking how dangerous conspiracy theories and cults like QAnon could take hold, how seemingly good people could believe such bad things, but I knew. It is exactly what my first book is about. 

 As I write, I hear the ping of an email in my inbox. The name in the subject line stops me cold: William Jeffrey Poole. The name I’d just written out of the story of my life. The person I had decided to not include in my memoir, because it was too complicated. 

 I expect the email to be routine, likely from some investigator assigned to Jeff’s military secret clearance renewal, tasked with contacting people from his past to ask them a standard list of questions. But that is not what I find at all. 

“Our office is currently working on a show-cause elimination board for MAJ William Jeffrey Poole,” the email reads. There is pending legal action and they want me to testify about his character. “The issue mainly arises from allegations which are broadly outlined in this Military Times article.” 

A show-cause board is meant to literally “show a cause” for why a soldier should be retained in service. If they can’t, his career and reputation are over. 
When I click the link to the article, I can’t believe what I am seeing, what he is being accused of. Except that I can. Just like the indicators I’d been trained to notice in intelligence work, I could see it all now with perfect clarity. The chapter of my life I’d never been able to understand all falls into place, and I know at that moment that writing UNCULTURED won’t be enough. I am going to have to write Jeff back into the story of my life, braiding and unbraiding it all, to figure out what happened. 

Because the thing that strikes me like the flash of a bomb, seemingly all at once but really a culmination of a lifetime of training in extremism, radicalization, armies, terrorists, us versus them mentality, group behavior, and cults, is that none of this happened to me by chance. 

I know this: it is because I’d been born and raised in a child-trafficking, extremist religious sex-cult that, years ago, I’d accidentally married a violent, extremist, white supremicist.

episodes.title: Episode 2 | White Women and Black Hair: Bridging the Gap
episodes.description:
In this episode, the conversation begins with a personal anecdote from Daniella about a ceramic bowl filled with pearls, which becomes a metaphor for the delicate and often fraught nature of discussing race and identity. The discussion quickly shifts to experiences with crafting and how the act of handling pearls becomes a soothing, almost ASMR-like activity, highlighting the sensory and emotional impact of seemingly simple actions.

The dialogue then delves into the significant emotional journey of embracing natural hair, particularly for Black women. Daniella and Rebecca explore the challenges of navigating societal standards that deem natural hair unprofessional or inappropriate. They recount personal stories of microaggressions and microinvalidations, such as unwanted hair touching and the implications of comments on their appearance. These experiences are contextualized within broader systemic issues, drawing parallels to military regulations that impose strict hair standards, often disadvantaging women and people of color.

The episode highlights the profound impact of hair control as a form of coercive power, both in personal and professional settings. Daniella shares insights from her military career, illustrating how stringent appearance standards serve as tools for harassment and assault, reinforcing hierarchical power structures. Rebecca emphasizes the cultural significance of hair in Black communities, noting how these societal pressures affect mental health and self-esteem from a young age.
The discussion culminates in a broader reflection on deconstructing white supremacy and challenging established norms. Daniella and Rebecca advocate for embracing authenticity over conformity, encouraging listeners to question and dismantle the purity requirements imposed by society. By sharing their journeys and encouraging open conversations, they aim to create a more inclusive and understanding environment where individuality is celebrated rather than suppressed.

episodes.title: The Myth of White Supremacy and the Process of Deprogramming
episodes.description:
In this conversation, Daniella Mestyanek Young and Rebecca discuss their experiences with cults and the deconstruction of white supremacy. They explore the stages of leaving a cult and the process of deprogramming from the myth of white supremacy. They also touch on topics such as privilege, racism, and the impact of cult dynamics on society. The conversation highlights the need for self-reflection, questioning societal norms, and working towards equality. Takeaways
There are three stages of leaving a cult: waking up, cracking the brainwashing, and physically and mentally leaving the cult.
Deconstructing from the myth of white supremacy requires a process of deprogramming that can take years.
White supremacy is like a cult, and deconstructing it involves questioning societal norms and recognizing the impact of privilege and racism.
Cult dynamics, such as the need to defend the good intentions of the group, can be observed in white supremacy and other systems of oppression.
Recognizing and challenging the sacred assumptions of white supremacy is essential for dismantling the system and creating equality. Recognize and reflect on your own privilege and the systems of white supremacy and patriarchy that perpetuate inequality.
Challenge and dismantle oppressive systems by actively working to create change.
Embrace vulnerability and use your voice to spread awareness and inspire others to take action.
Question and deconstruct your own beliefs and behaviors to ensure they align with your values and promote equality.
Find ways to live authentically and resist the pressures of capitalism and societal expectations.
Use art and creativity as a means of personal growth and self-expression.
